reviews.review: A building with a history and old, but well-maintained. I took the guided tour which went all the way to the top of the building (including the lighthouse room) and took in fantastic 360 degree views of the city of Buenos Aires. The guide was very informative in both English and Spanish, and explained the practical aspects of the still-functioning private offices as well as the decorative connections to Dante's Inferno. There is a small museum space (two rooms converted from former offices) that contains a few more artifacts of the building's long history.Tours are only offered at certain times, are limited due to the small size of the spaces at the top of the building, and sometimes book out days in advance, so you may wish to book your tour well in advance, especially if you are planning to go on a weekday or holiday.The Congreso of Argentina is just down the street across the park from the Palacio Barolo and offers free tours at certain times of day (I think the afternoon), so you may wish to do both in one day, if you plan it well.
Fascinating!. This is a fascinating building and tribute to the Divine Comedy. The tour is a must-do in Buenos Aires.

A not-so-well-known secret!. Most people living in Buenos Aires know about this place, but never been to it. This is one of the most amazing buildings I've ever seen. Designed by a masonic architect and ordered by a very rich guy, the place is dedicated to Dante Alighieri, intended to be his burial site (at least that was the owner's dream). The building is themed, it's all about the Divine Comedy and it's floors are divided into Hell, Purgatory and Heaven, so each section is decorated acordingly: Hell is very baroque, lots of details and symbolism. As you go up, level of detail is less and less and in Heaven, it's all very clean, with almost no detail.There's a guided tour (there's in english too) and they take you to the top of the building where there's a lighthouse in a very tall building with great sights of Downtown and the Congress building. Don't miss this place!

Amazing night tour with tango. Their night tour extravaganza with tango is amazing. We were a group of 6 people and had the most amazing evening exploring the building with a knowledgable guide who spoke Spanish and English. We spend 2 hours looking through different areas of the building from bottom all the way to the top of the lighthouse. Being in the lighthouse was amazing especially at night with light being on and moving around. The hight also offered best views of the city at night which were amazing. Fantastic night tour which I would highly recommend if you have time. The tour is only selected nights per week so please check with their box office and book in advance as it gets very booked up and busy. There is a number of narrow steps to climb so not suitable for people who have fear of closed spaces, difficulties to climb or walk or scared of heights.

Intriguing Architecture (Money + Art = ?). Palacio Barolo built by two Italian immigrant friends (one with the money from his textile business, the other the architect) in 1923 was for a long time the tallest building in BA at 22 floors plus a light house. Build in Eclectic style, is the twin of Palacio Salvo built in Montevideo, Uruguay. The two partners, built this building using as a theme Dante's Divina Comedia. The basement and ground floors having been designated as Inferno (Hell), contain decorations representing Inferno. There are dragons, monsters and Masonic symbols everywhere. The next second through the 14 floors are designated as Purgatory, while floors 15 through 22 represent Heaven. THere is a light house, hosting a very powerful Klieg light designed to illuminate across the estuary of Rio de la Plata all the way to where it was to meet a beam from a similar light from Palacio Salvo in Montevideo. Alas, this plan did not quite work, though the lighthouse and its light are still functional today. It is worth a visit and the fee is nominal for a tour that is well conducted in Spanish, Portuguese and Englis by very competent young guides, while the spectre of Dante Aligeri (another guide, actor) pops up from time to time to recite a passage from his opus magnum, the Divine Comedy. There are daily tours (about 90 minutes) during the day and evening. The evening tours (8:00 pm) end up in an office set up as at the beginning of the 20th century, on the 20th floor where a violin is playing while the guests are offered a glass of wine. The 10 PM tour does not offer the wine or the violin but has a surprise in the light house. Worth visiting.

Fantastic views & Interesting Tour. We did the night tour, which included a tango performance and wine tasting at the end. The tour provided the history of the building, traveling throughout to review the hidden symbolism in the work. Our tour guide switched between Spanish & English, asking to know who the English speakers were beforehand so that he spoke directly to us, which I thought was a nice touch. Keep in mind it is a tight winding staircase to get to the top, but the views once you get there are incredible!

Nice views, enjoyable tour. We reserved the tour via e-mail, very easy and without pre-paying. Specially worthy if you are interested in architecture, the tour was carried out in an hour and a half, you visit the first floors (the most decorated of the building) and the upper floors just up to the lantern (don't climb if you are claustrophobic, but you have very good views from the stage below as well). Last 6 floors are by stairs, because there is no lift, but the guide gives you plenty of time to climb if you need it. You have very nice views of Buenos Aires, and more than enough time to take pictures. At last you visit an apartment with furniture and photographs of the time when the building was finished. The guide was a very nice girl who told us all about the history of the building and made the visit very amusing (Unluckily I can't remember her name). The price, 160 ARS, may be a little expensive, but for me it worths the money.
Fascinating Tour - Brilliant views. Be ready to climb very narrow winding staircase to the top, but worth the view when finally get to the top. Curious history of this art-deco building on Av Mayo

A hallmark for Buenos Aires. The palace has an interesting story and history, well integrated in the history of Buenos Aires. The architecture is very special and from the top of the building you can have a stunning view of the city. We had an excellent guide (young guy, I regret that do not remember the name), who gave all explanations in both Spanish and English and was very careful with many details. I strongly recommend a visit of Palacio Barolo!

Well worth a visit, great views. My husband and I did this tour today and thought it was really worth while. We had great views from the 20th Floor and I enjoyed learning about how the building's design was inspired by the Devine Comedy.Would recommend booking in advance, easy to do by email as the company replied straight away.

Worth a visit. The building has a lot of potential, which is not taken advantage of.First, the lobby (ground floor) is the really only part of the building that has true architecture that one can link to the Divina Comedia. It seems that all the money was spent here; the rest of the interior is very simple. In any case because of its history the visit is worth it. I also recommend that the visitor go up the stairs to the very last floor. 6 floors up the stairs. It would have been more appropriate if it cost 120 pesos, and not 200. But, it is a nice visit considering its history.

One of the most interesting buildings in Buenos Aires.. Lot of marble and incredible architecture ,two elevators with cylinder shape and a powerful light on top of the building like a light house in the city.
ARCHITECTURE with great views and literary reminicences. A Great Great building inspired by La Divina Comedia of Dante. Go up from hell to Paradise. At the top, an extraordinary view of the city.

Great views and tour. Friendly ticket staff and a great guide showed us round speaking alternately in English first: just for me, and Spanish second for the others in the group. The tour really explains the history and design of the building very well and the original lifts you go up in are an experience in themselves. The balconies below the lighthouse have great views over the city but the narrow spiralling stair up to the actual glass lantern of the original lighthouse at the very top, 100m above the ground was a fabulous surprise and it's a really unique experience all round. Highly recommended to any visitor to Buenos Aires.

Very, very cool tour!. It was well worth the taxi ride and entrance fee of $200AR to do the 5pm day tour. The history and architecture are absolutely fascinating, and the exploration of the building and the lighthouse was amazing!! The tour was about 90 minutes, so plan ahead. We had heard it was only 45 minutes. Also, the last stair climb up from the 14th floor to the lighthouse level and the lighthouse itself is a doozy! The 8? flights of stairs are crazy narrow and tricky to navigate. But the view from both of the top levels is amazing as one would expect from the 2nd tallest building in South America!!

Amazing views from the top!. I love getting a good view of a city, and I found Palacio Barolo online and decided to do the tour. I was not disappointed! I did the last tour of the evening at 6pm without booking in advance. I just walked up and purchased tickets before the time, and I am glad I did the evening tour because I got a gorgeous view of the sunset over the city. The guide was knowledgeable and the history of the building is fascinating. He even took great photos of everyone at the top with the city in the background and posted them on Facebook for us to download. Highly recommend for interesting history and the best view of Buenos Aires!

Great building but the staff let it down. What a beautiful and unique building but what an unprofessional procedure to buy tickets, tried online several times but they respond a week later or not at all. Still waiting for a response. Eventually got our hotel to call and book. Upon arrival a very rude girl sitting in the booth did not say hello just barks out an amount. Tour guide was brilliant and spoke in English and Spanish and was very informative. Well worth the visit but do something about the e mail booking system and rude staff.

Great historic building!. We took the tour not really knowing what to expect. We found a great historic building. The tour guide was great speaking English (well) and Spanish. He had lots of information on the building's history. The lighthouse at the top was very cool. Be sure you are able to climb stairs though, you need to climb up six flights to the top. It does get a bit cramped as you get to the top as well. Overall great tour.

Interesting architecture. Quite unique and once the highest building in South America. Amazing architecture and if you do not have time for a tour, just to see externally and go into the main entrance will give you some idea of this palace.
a true jewel a must visit for Architecture lovers. Amazing, impressive, splendorous, you will not be disappointed!get your camera ready cause is a real beauty.

Amazing Experience!. Travelled to the Palacio Barolo with Mente Argentina study abroad group, had such a great experience, especially seeing the city at night. Sky scrapers for days! Such an interesting place to visit. Highly recommend!

something different in Bs As. It´s just in downtown. It´s a different building. You can do the guided tour and you arrive at the highest part of it where you can see the whole city. The whole tour takes 50 minutes. It´s better to book a place in the tour. You will enjoy it. You can also do the night tour where you will taste some wine and watch a tango show.

Is a trip back to 1920, full of surprises and great views. This tour is a must do in Buenos Aires, unfortunately it only can be done Saturdays or Sundays. But really worth it 100 %. The history involved on the construction of this great tower building is very interesting, the panoramic views from the top balconys are amazing in the early afternoon the colours of the city that you can see are wonderful. As it is 110 meters above sea level the views are incredible. The light house on the top is worth the effort to get there.
Past glory !. Argentina used to be the 7th economy of the planet...in 1920. This building was built when the country had a great future. Worth to take a look

Incredible views. My husband and I joined a group of 7 for the midday tour. We were the only non-Spanish speakers in the group. Our tour guide was not only knowledgeable but very friendly to us all and answered all the questions posed to him in both languages. He took lovely pictures of us all when we got to the very top and posted them on his group Facebook page for us to download freely. Completely recommend. I might add though, that a reasonable level of fitness is required for the final 6 levels of narrow circular stairs to the very top. So worth the effort.

Wonderful surprise. We took the guided tour and are so pleased we did. It was entertaining, fascinating and great value. There are so many gorgeous details that the designer thought out. I loved the dragon and condor gargoyles in the main floor lobby. The view from the top was amazing and a great way to see the city and how dense it is. We also loved the old-fashioned elevators (the cages) and the open balconies that allowed us to take great photos from up on high. Perfect view of the Plaza del Congreso from up there.

Building, view, tour guides. Yes! Worth 90 minutes. Not sure.... Palacio Barolo is a beautiful building with an interesting history. Our tour guide was energetic and gracious in accommodating my partner who was the only non-Spanish speaker in the group. The view from the top is stunning (at least part of it) but I am not sure it is worth a 90 minute tour... Part of the reason the tour takes so long is the fact that building has had no major renovations since it was opened in early 1900s. The elevators move at the same speed and only take 8 passengers at a time. Given that the building is still a fully operational office space, this could mean a fair amount of waiting (as you move throughout the building) if you are in a large tour group. If your time is limited in Buenos Aires you may want to consider using that 90 minutes elsewhere.

Great Views & Interesting Information. For about $16 US per person, this tour was a great value. The English speaking tour guide took us through the design and construction of the Palacio, which employs symbolism from Dante's Divine Comedy. From hell (the lobby, which is beautiful) through Purgatory (middle floors) and into Paradise (last few floors), we were provided with insights about the design throughout. It was a great supplement to the main event: the views.We were taken to a room near the top of Palacio Barolo and told we could open any balcony doors we pleased and step outside. Being from the overly safety conscious US, this was a wonderful surprise! There are plenty of balconies, just large enough to fit 3(ish) people. The balconies provide panoramic views of the city or the river, depending on your position.The guide then took us up a very, very narrow staircase to the apex of the building; the lighthouse. Though no longer in use as a beacon for ships, we sat for a short time for additional historical info, and snapped photos of the 360 degree views.The entire tour was about 90 minutes, and a great use of time. Finish that off with a walk to Cafe Tortoni for coffee and medialunas, and you will not go wrong.

Great expectations leads to great dissappointment. Reading reviews of the place I expected a lot more about the Divine comedy than what I got. The tour as such is pretty good, in the sense that the guide was funny and engaging and spoke good english. But the actual parallels to the Divine comedy was a bit of a stretch. Granted they wanted to do this up as a tribute to the great Dante, but other than a lot of math, there is hardly much art. Moreover, as the place is a commercial building there is not much lighting during the evening tour that we took. We did the tour plus tango show and the latter was an incredible let down. I am sure the dancers were very talented, but given that they had only a tiny space in which to twirl around ( I dont think I am exaggerating much if I say it was not more that a 10X12 space!) and we were all jam-packed into that tiny space, standing up, with them it was not at all an enjoyable experience! The views from the top, are spectacular. Like other reviewers have said, the last bit up to the "lighthouse" is up a set of increasingly narrow, concrete steps and not recommended for those who suffer from vertigo. All in all, I would say do the evening tour just for the view, dont pay the extra for any show and do it only if you have an evening to kill.
Great view from the top. Very interesting Building. This around 100 year old building offers a great view over Buenos Aires. Definitely worth visiting!

Dante would have loved it here!!. Exceptional tour done by a beautiful lad called Nacho. His hair was to die for and his passion for his job was very evident.The 6pm tour lasted an hour and a half. We had planned on taking in the cello concert @8pm Thursday nights but.....a misunderstanding due to the fact that I speak very little Spanish resulted in not repeating the tour @8 pm and waiting until 9:30 to hear the concert. Had I understood I would have just booked the 8pm tour. Next time? The tour is wonderful and Nacho made it even better! Cheers Nacho!

For Lovers of Dante, a must see. . I booked a night tour, in which they turn on the light at the top of the building. It is a lovely view of the city, even on a rainy night. The guide was very good and spoke excellent English and was fun. The Building is beautiful and very interesting part of the BA city history and demonstrates the huge influence of Italian and Europe had on the city. And the wealth that was here.

Beautiful views of the city was the highlight. I was under the impression that we'd be going to a building that was very obviously relating to Dante's inferno with beautiful art depictions. Could have been my fault for not doing the research but it didn't seem too related to the Divine Comedy. It was more about the Free Mason symbols and the symbols that related to Dante. That being said, the building is beautiful, our tour guide was very friendly and did the tour in Spanish and English (I think you got more out of it if you speak Spanish), and the views at the top are beautiful. I think for 100 pesos more I'd do the tango show with wine and it would have been better.

Fascinating tour . You have to visit with a tour, but our guide was interesting & funny so that was fine. We went in the day & didn't pre-book. The views are great; just make sure you don't go during heavy rain as you can't go to the very top of the lighthouse. The building itself is also fascinating, and the explanation of the architecture is great.

What A View!! You MUST book in advance!!. We booked the 7pm tour the following day via email which was very quickly responded to. Sun was just setting but by the time we reached the tower it was dark and the city was sparkling with lights, so beautiful. It is a great place to get a high 360 view of the city. Tour guide was very friendly and knowledgable. Really recommend it!!

Night Tour of The Barolo Building. This tour wasn't originally high on my list of things to do in B.A, but I just happened to be passing by the building 10 minutes before it started and they allowed me to join.Everyone else had pre booked, and as this tour gets busy I would suggest that you book in advance. The cost (March 2016) is 200 peso's for foreigners.The tour is conducted in Spanish (and English if required). The guide was knowledgeable, humorous and entertaining. She also took the time to explain everything clearly in English even though I was the only English speaker out of 20 people In the group. The architecture is symbolic and you get hear about the design concepts and how the Italian architects based many of the features on Dante's Divine Comedy. There are also some Masonic connections which are also interesting to hear about.The tour ascends through various levels in the building until you reach the viewing balconies and lighthouse at the top. I would recommend the night tour as its great to see the city lit up from a high perspectives and you also get to see the lighthouse working.If you have even a vague interest in history or architecture, or you just want to get a good view over the city to take some photographs then this tour is for you.This was one of the highlights of my visit to B.A. and I thoroughly recommend a tour of the Barolo Palace.

Difficult to see from the street. I'm not sure how people got the photos I have seen on various sites, as it was difficult to see this building from street level. Perhaps they walked further away, although from what I could see the Gothic architecture looked impressive.

Lighthouse in the middle of the city!. This building has great architecture and a fascinating story. Take the tour to enjoy the views from the lighthouse at the top of the building. Yes, there's a lighthouse in the middle of Buenos Aires. The tour guide took photos of us and posted them to Facebook later that evening.
Must see!. Is a beautiful building with a lot of history behind, the best time to visit is at night because you can go to the light house ans see all the city.
Good. Didn't spent a lot of time here. Was part of the walking tour. Guide said that there are 9 archs, 9 elevators inside, somekind of 9 numerical in everything inside. beautiful architecture.ity.

An arquitects dream!. Such a beautiful building, build according to Dante´s Divine Comedy. Get the guided tour, you´ll end up high up in the light house - if you´re afraid of hights this is NOT your place to be. A bit touristy but well worth it because of the insight on this impressive building.

Great tour; great guide. We first arrived too late for the last daily trip, so booked for 10am next day. We had no idea what to expect and went along purely for the view and photographs.We were immediately impressed with the guide. Anna-Maria asked if there were any English speakers, and then led the tour in two languages. And it was the full content in English, not just the truncated, stunted English version. The story and history were fascinating and the views all we expected. If you only have time for one thing in Buenos Aires ( as we did), then spend 90 minutes on the tour here.

Amazing view, great tour, do it!. We arrived at 10am ready for the first tour so only 5 of us. Really interesting, lovely guide who spoke perfect English. Cost about £7 each. Unbelievable view from the very top (but don't do it if you suffer from vertigo or are unfit as you won't enjoy the last bit!)
Beautiful example of Argentine buildings. Saw from bus and went back for a closer look. Area hustle and bustle, but the grounds and building g are nice to see.

Most beautiful and fascinating building in Buenos Aires. We didn't spent a lot of time here, but if you enjoy unusual and beautiful architecture, this building is a must. Great style and grace and really a focal point of the city.

Beautiful building worth a visit. Interesting and beautiful building that you can't appreciate fully unless you take a tour. We took the regular building tour and learned and saw how the building was inspired by Dante's Inferno. The tour guide was knowledgeable and answered questions for us. The best part was the view of the city from the top.

Poor cousin of the MVD palacio. Both Palacios by Palanti should be visited. After the Montevideo one, the BA cousin was disappointing, run done and lack of show rooms! It was only thanks to cheerful Mara and other visitors in the group that we enjoyed the visit until the end!

Impressive and intriguing . A must see if you love architecture and history. The entire design and interior is inspired by Dante's Divine Comedy, every detail represents an insight from this great and iconic piece of literature. A 360 degrees view from the top of the building is worth every penny!Not suitable for people who have vertigo and/ or can't cope in closed in and small areas.

An intriguing building.. This building is not a Palace in the strict sense of the word but a very intriguing building, which was a result of the imagination of architect Mario Palanti and paid for by Businessman Barolo.
Visit the top!. This is one of the two sister buildings. The other one is in Montevideo, Uruguay. The views from the tops are absolutely great!
Wonderful Building. The daytime guided tour was awesome, full of interesting information. The building is beautiful and the view from the lighthouse is breathtaking.

Don't miss the night tour of this fantastic building!. This may be one of the most interesting and fascinating buildings in the world. Learn its history, the story behind its design as a homage to Dante's "Divine Comedy", and get an unbelieveable nightime panorama of Buenos Aires from the lighthouse 100 meters up.

Interesting and informative tour, plus great views!. This fascinating old building, created as a mausoleum and an homage to Dante's Divine Comedy, is not accessible unless you have an appointment at one of its businesses or purchase a guided tour. Tickets are a bit pricey, but the 1-hour tour is definitely worth it! You get to hear fascinating descriptions of the history and architecture, given by a guide who speaks excellent English (the tour is given simultaneously in English and Spanish). It requires some climbing -- about 6 stories -- but after that plus a ride in a gorgeous and historic elevator, you have the most amazing view of the city from a glass lighthouse. Warning: this is not a good tour for people who are claustrophobic (tiny, narrow staircases) or acrophobia (the balconies and lighthouse are extremely vertigo-inducing).

Beautiful view of the city! Lighthouse is so fun!. The backstory is what really drew me to this place...coupled with its amazing architecture, of course! But what left a lasting impression was the view of the city from the top. And the lighthouse is tiny but so fun to climb, a truly great experience. My tour guide was awesome too, so informative and fun!

Wonderful palace with nice view from the top. Each time when I am in BA, I go to visit Palacio Barolo. Simply for me this is a must to make elevator tour and take a view from the top on Congreso and Casa de Rosada ... There are also nice stories to hear if you take guided tour.

Astonishing building!!!. I was born in Buenos Aires and consider myself a curious person who knows the city very well but I must admit that the visit I paid to this palace some weeks ago was completely jaw dropping! My advice is to take the last Sunday tour to get an awsome view of the city at sunset and the lighthouse is lit. Yes, a lighthouse in the heart of the Buenos Aires! The building is said to be devoted to Dante Alighieri´s Divine Comedy. You do start from Hell, go up to the Purgatory and finaly reach Heaven in defined stages when all your feelings rise galloping through the beauty of the construction while observing the excellent condition the building is kept. Take your camera and a couple of hours to enjoy art, architecture, history, fantasy, and last but not least, a touching approach to Masonry. Believe it or not, definitely a tour to remember!!!!

Beautiful building, has a story to tell.... Entrance hall can be visited, no fee to pay. In order to visit the whole building a ticket must be payed, but this includes a guide (available in different languages). It worth taking it!!!

My favourite building in Buenos Aires. A tip. Look for the guide Eduardo Lazzari on the internet. Ask for a private tour on Sunday at 11am, 1pm, 3pm or 5pm. Fantastic tour. If you wand to do the night tour, from Monday to Saturday.

Nice view over the city!. I've taken a tour through Palacio Barolo which was done by an enthousiastic tour guide which spoke very good English. From the top of the building you have a very nice view over the city and is one of the only buildings in town which gives you a 360 degree view.

interesting architecture. The building has interesting architecture with an interesting connection to Dante's Divine Comedy but as a tour its a bit contrived and expensive for what it is. You get a good view of the city from the top

Tour at Palacio Barolo. This is a very interesting building. We took this tour on the New Year eve day, so there were not too many people and we were able to walk in and book an organized trip 30 minutes prior. The tour guide was knowledgeable and spoke in both Spanish and English. This tour is not recommended to people who are afraid of height and able to walk up the very narrow stairs. The building itself is one of a kind, built back in 1919-1923. The architecture is very unique. You're able to go up to a 23 floor, from hell to heaven and take the most amazing pictures of the city.
Beautiful vistas. Beautiful vistas and well paced tour. Excellent overview and information on this historic landmark. Well worth a visit.

Brilliant tour . Really enjoyed the tour with the English speaking tour guide. The history of the building was really interesting and the architecture was gorgeous. The view from the top was extraordinary, so glad I went.

Unique views of Buenos Aires. The Palazio Barolo offers a fascintaing guided tour of this tremendous building which is full of symbolism from Dante's Divine Comedy and was formerly the tallesz skyscraper in Buenos Aires.The 360 degree panaromic views from the 'lighthouse' are a real highlight.Warning: the stairs to get to the lighthouse and extremely narrow and the headroom is low.The entrance price is 170 pesos and the tours leave regularly and take about an hour.

Regret not going up. I found and spotted this beautiful building just after returning from Montevideo, where it's sister building Palacio Salvo is on the main sq and you cannot miss it.BA has much more to offer than Montevideo and just the fact that such great bldg is in a middle of the street difficult to spot proves it.

Awesome Place. This is the sister Palacio to Palacio Salvo in Montevideo, very impressive architecture, our hotel (Tango de Mayo Hotel) we stayed in, is right next door to this Impressive Palacio well worth the fee for the tour

Wonderful view and fantastic building. We booked the guided tour organised by Professor Eduardo Lazzari, a local eminence in architecture and history. The visit was very interesting, including the historical context of the rising of this building. Wonderful. The view from the lighthouse is the cherry on the cake! Don't leave Buenos Aires without this visit, it takes just two hours and is totally worth it.

Not for the faint of heart. The building is close to the Plaza del Congreso and you can just look at its rooftop from the street. But if you want to see the inside you have to take one of the different tours available - during the day or at nighttime. All tours require advance reservation - give them a call the day before your intended tour (call after 12) -, you cannot just show up and hope there's an empty spot (this may be good or bad). The price of the tours vary - I took the photographic one, which is only offered once a month, lasts 2 hours and costs 250 pesos.The tour allows for some time (normal strolling plus stops for photos) in the main lobby, then the antique elevators. After checking two of the floors (we were also able to see an office decorated a l'epoque), the visitors climb 6 floors (narrow staircase) to the viewpoint. Here are 6 doors and small balconies to see the view (from rooftops to Evita's face on the television building, from the River Plata to the airplanes taking off from Newberry and Ezeiza). The safety measures seem very lax so:* Please secure all items (including the visitor tag) and tie your hair before getting out on the balconies, the wind and air draft makes everything fly and you don't want to have to grab them. * Pay attention to the balcony doors - when more are open, the air draft makes then close unexpectedly and with a very loud noise - if you are on the balcony, that's enough to make you jump :-) or give you a heart attack. So you may want to hold the door while staying on each balcony.From the viewpoint, an even narrower (and low ceiling-ed) staircase takes you to the light room, where there's a small space to sit, almost directly on the glass walls and floor of the lighthouse. Move carefully, the mirror is rotating and there's no holding rail or support.

Amazing views. Done an evening tour with these guys - informative and with snacks at the end. To be honest, I really only went for the views and they were 100% worth it, given the clear evening we had. The views across all over BA are simply spectacular.

Spectacular views and a great trip to the past. El Palacio Barolo, built on the epic poem by Dante Alighieri, The Divine Comedy, attempts to represent the three stages of travel of the soul through Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise or Heaven. This is expressed in the wonderful sculptures, paintings and decorations throughout the building. Although it is still for private use, there are tours that charge a nominal fee. Best time is at night.
amazing sight. I lived in Buenos Aires and I never went inside this building but it is amazing looking on the outside.
Not if you don't like heights!,. Great tour to hear all the history but if you hate heights give the lighthouse at the very top a big miss!,

Beautiful building, amazing view. This is truly an impressive building and well worth the visit, if only for the climb to the very top of it in the lighthouse. The view on BA from there is fantastic and you can make wonderful panoramic pictures. The guided tour is interesting but a bit limited as, besides the Dante/Mason story about the building, there is not much to see inside (nice elevators, old fashioned office). The real interest is the general view of the building and the view from the top. Rather expensive but worth it, if sunny. (We did the short day tour, there is also along night tour including a glass of wine and a night view of the city that might be worth trying)
Beautiful. The building has a beautiful design, you can enter for free to chek the lobby - visitng the rest of the building is charged. Amazing structure very well preserved, elevators are very nice!

If you love Il Dante you must visit it. When in Buenos Aires go to the Barolo Palace, a placefull of history and mystery. Luis Barolo an Italian who came to Argentina at the end of the 19th century and became a millionaire together with his architect Mario Palanti ,another Italian represented in this building Dante's Divine Comedy. As you enter t he place you get into the Inferno and as you ascend the stairs, which become narrower and narrower you get into Heaven. The building is 100 meters tall and at its top there is a lighthouse. You have marvellous views of the city of Buenos Aires from the top.

Dante's Divine Comedy’s cosmology in a building!. Palacio Barolo is a landmark office building (including travel agencies, a Spanish school for foreigners, a Tango clothing store and offices for accountants, lawyers, etc.), located on 1370 Mayo Avenue, in the neighborhood of Monserrat, near the National Congress. When it was built it was the tallest building in South America. Built in Eclectic style, it was declared a National Historic Monument in 1997.Structure of the building: designed in accordance with the cosmology of Dante's Divine Comedy. The 22 floors (as the cantos in Dante’s poem) are divided into three "sections": the basement and the ground floor represent Hell. After that (floors 1-14), the Purgatory. Finally, floors 15 to 22 and the lighthouse on the top, Paradise. It is amazing how light plays a more important role the upper you climb. A clear symbol of Heaven/Paradise. The Lighthouse: used to be used for optical communication with a twin building in Montevideo, Uruguay (Palacio Salvo).Some Gothic and Islamic reminiscences are found. Both the architect and owner’s plans were to bring Dante’s remains to be buried in the Palace, something which – unfortunately – could not be achieved. What the ticket includes: a guided tour and a plus: all the way up to a glass light house. However, be warned: the small narrow passage of circular and twisting stairways, iron-gated elevators and tight passages leading to the top are not for everyone. What’s more, it can get claustrophobic. But once you get on top, if you do, the views – from tiny balconies - are spectacular! Afternoon and evening guided tours. The latter includes wine tasting, so it is a bit more expensive. Tip: pay attention to details, including those of the façade. Guides: VERY friendly and flexible (with had a problem with our reservation. However, they were so nice. They even provided me with their mobile phone numbers. They are two brothers, related somehow to the building).HIGHLY recommend. Should be on your “must-see” list. Wonderful panoramic shots! Eye-popping definitely!

Great tour guide, building a bit disappointing, fantastic views. I went for a tour on a Monday at 4pm. I recall the cost was 60 pesos. Our tour guide, Tomas, was excellent in both Spanish and English. The tour took about 35-40 minutes. We were about 12 people.The Palacio Barolo is a functioning office building inspired by Dante's Divine Comedy. Most of the representation is symbolic. For example, the number of floors would equal the number of chapters, etc.The building is divided into 3 regions to represent Heaven, Purgatory, and Hell. The ground floor is supposed to represent Hell with designs in the floor symbolizing the fires of hell, and certain wall ornaments depicting dragons and demons. The architect had intended for the building to house the ashes of Dante, but his petition to the Italian authorities was denied; so the building lost part of its raison d'être.The middle floors represent Purgatory, with a central atrium enabling both views upward and downward. These are mostly boring offices. There are a few flights of stairs to climb.Heaven is represented by the observatory deck at the top of a very narrow, railless staircase. I do not recommend this climb for anyone with a fear of enclosed spaces or any morbidly obese person. At the top, there are small balconies from which you can take the best panoramic photos of the city. That alone is worth the cost of admission, although there may be shops on higher floors that have similar views for free.Tomas recommended other sights in the city, especially the excellent El Zanjon.I would not call this a must-see, but certainly worth it if you're in the Congreso area already. The building was influenced by Dante's Divine Comedy. The floor of entrance of the building has patterned medallions to give the impression of fire in hell. Great place to take pics of the city. This building intrigued us from the outside so we decided to take a gander on the inside. It was our dumb luck that there was a tour starting in 2 min at 2:00. The Italian architect Mario Palanti was commissioned to design the building by the empresario Luis Barolo, an Italian immigrant who had arrived in Argentina in 1890 and had made a fortune in knitted fabrics. It was designed in accordance with the cosmology of Dante's Divine Comedy, motivated by the architect's admiration for Alighieri. There are 22 floors, divided into three "sections". The basement and ground floor represent hell, floors 1-14 are the purgatory, and 15-22 represent heaven. The building is 100 meters (328 feet) tall, one meter for each canto of the Divine Comedy. The lighthouse at the top of the building can be seen all the way in Montevideo, Uruguay. The owner planned to use only 3 floors (with secret elevators), and to rent the rest. When completed in 1923 it was the tallest building, not only in the city, but also in the whole of South America. It remained the city's tallest building until 1935 when, on completion, the Kavanagh Building took over this title. The tour came out to $40 AR well with the $10 us for the pictures of Congress and the unobstructed views of the city. They do wine tasting tours on Friday evening where they drink good wine and then take a hike up to the top of the lighthouse.

We were lucky enough to arrive on a Thursday and were able to get an English tour of this beautiful building inspired by Dante Alighieri's "Divine Comedy." The tour takes you to the rooftop lighthouse where there are 360 degree spectacular views of Buenos Aires. There are especially beautiful views of the Congreso building. The tour guide, Miqueas, is very well informed about the building and was a wonderful tour guide. We are happy that we took this tour because we were able to get a great view of the city. We went in the the afternoon but there are also evening tours plus wine tastings.

Astonishing!. I had read about this building in one of the many tourist guides and handouts I had been given at the first place I stayed, and then happened upon it one day with a new Argentinian friend and his architect partner. It's an amazing building, and curious in that it was built based on Dante's "Inferno"- from hell to purgatory and eventually Heaven. I told them I thought you could go inside it and take a tour, so we asked and were told how to arrange it. A few days later, we met back there for the small tour (which happened to be in Spanish), but fortunately my friend Matías was a good translator. There were probably only about 8 of us on the tour and they had an English handout for us. I felt like I had discovered the Empire State Building of Buenos Aires, and an unknown secret. We went up and up and up, and suddenly were outside on these little round outcroppings of the cupola. The view was 360 degrees, and up and down Avenida de Mayo- from the Casa Rosada (the Pink House) to the Congresso. Absolutely astonishing. And then, we went up a couple at a time to the very tippy top, to the light house. Truly incredible. We felt as if we had shared in a special Buenos Aires secret where few tourists venture.
